Hay ! My second fan-art thread for me, since this picture doesn't fit my GIMP Space Art thread, because it is done entirely in Blender 2.65 and Internal Render:

The 2K image is here: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/98670603/KSP/spaceart/Kerbin-rise_2K.png

The 1080p one took ~16min to render, while the 2K one took ~25min. Rendered Mun's surface, Kerbin and its atmosphere separately, then put together using the Nodes Editor (how powerful are they ^^)

Edited April 24, 2013 by SolarLiner
Going is with a G, not a C ...
Not bad. The Mun's surface looks too pointy but otherwise I like it.
Nice render, not a fan of the Mun surface to be honest(looks a tad blurry to me, almost like i need 3d glasses)
Love the Kerbin, but the Mun's surface is way to jagged in my opinion.
Theres a problem, Why the south pole of kerbin is in dark, and the north pole is directly pointing at Kerbol?

The 1080p one took ~16min to render, while the 2K one took ~25min. Rendered Mun's surface, Kerbin and its atmosphere separately, then put together using the Nodes Editor (how powerful are they ^^)
What did you use for your Kerbin texture?

Very nice,

However the moon terrain seems a bit more like it's something on kerbin (as in it looks eroded)

other than that it looks great

Sorry for late reply (didn't saw the comments ...)

First, the blurry mun land is the Lens Distortion effect (Nodes Editor). I took a sample directly from the bump map of the surface, so it looks blurry. I wanted a "Apollo 8" style render, with the surface and the planet behind.

Which may explain the incorrect lighting (thanks gmpd2000, I saw my error here). I put the light so the planet has this phase. What I should have done is put everything like normal, then rotate the camera: bam, everything's fine.

I didn't really like the render of the landscape too, but this as the best I can do for "in-game reality" accuracy. I'll try to combine bump map and custom generated features next time.

But I thank you everyone to write down these comments, and I appreciated that you liked the render !

One last thing: all the texture were found by a simple <body> map on Google Image search (ie "Kerbin map", or "Mun bump map" for the elevation map of it)
